reasoning:
1. Circle of Competence: Amazon operates at the crossroads of e-commerce, cloud services, logistics and media. That’s a far cry from the simple, predictable businesses I understand—like candy stores (See’s), insurance (GEICO) or consumer brands (Coca-Cola). I’d be flying blind in half the segments Amazon runs. When you don’t know a business, you expose yourself to risk. 

2. Competitive Moat: They’ve built a Prime ecosystem, scale in logistics and a leading cloud franchise in AWS. That shows pricing power—but it’s balanced by ruthless competition from Walmart, Microsoft and Google. We like moats that grow stronger with time; Amazon’s faces fierce trench warfare on every front.

3. Management & Capital Allocation: Jeff Bezos and Andy Jassy have shown vision—reinvesting heavily, often at the expense of near-term profits. That’s admirable for growth, but leaves owner earnings negative ($‒19,946M). I prefer managers who deliver steady free cash and return it to shareholders when they can’t reinvest at high returns.

4. Financial Health & Consistency: Return on equity is a weak 5.3%, ROIC just 2.0%, and debt/equity sits at 1.6x. Earnings are erratic—zero score for consistency—despite 236.6% growth over ten periods. A fortress should stand on rock, not shifting sands.

5. Valuation vs. Intrinsic Value: The three-stage DCF spits out a negative intrinsic value (even a conservative haircut yields –$305,519M). A margin of safety well below zero tells me the market price is too rich for the business’s current economics. 

6. Long-Term Prospects & Red Flags: E-commerce and cloud will be around in 20 years, but I worry about margin pressure, capital intensity and unpredictable technology shifts. Negative owner earnings and high reinvestment keep me up at night. 

7. Comparison to Our Portfolio: We’d rather own a wonderful business like Coca-Cola at a fair price than a complex, capital-hungry business at any price. There are more reliable moats and steadier cash flows in consumer staples, banks or insurance—places where Berkshire has had decades of success. 

In short, Amazon is too far outside my circle, with mixed fundamentals and no margin of safety. I’ll pass.

fundamental_analysis.details: Weak ROE of 5.3%; High debt to equity ratio of 1.6; Strong operating margins; Current ratio data not available

consistency_analysis.details: Inconsistent earnings growth pattern; Total earnings growth of 236.6% over past 10 periods

moat_analysis.details: Inconsistent ROE: only 0/10 periods >15%; Strong and stable operating margins (avg: 52.8%) indicate pricing power moat

book_value_analysis.details: Good book value per share growth pattern

management_analysis.details: No significant new stock issuance detected; No or minimal dividends paid

details: Using three-stage DCF: Stage 1 (8.0%, 5y), Stage 2 (4.0%, 5y), Terminal (2.5%)
